PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE:     Project Narrative Gastric carcinoma is the third most common cause of cancer related-death worldwide. According to the World Health Organization, National Cancer Institute, and epidemiological data, individuals with chronic H. pylori infection carry a 3 - to-6 fold higher ris of developing gastric cancer. Recent studies of U.S soldiers deployed to the Middle East and Far East have shown that the incidence of H. pylori infection was 7.3 percent per year compared to 2.5 percent of U.S. military recruits living at home, which represents a major increase in risk. PHR: In this project, we will determine whether people with cerebellar damage can 1) learn to improve reaching on a short time scale using a motor learning mechanism that does not rely on the cerebellum, 2) improve long term reaching performance from weeks of training and 3) benefit from individualized robotic assistance for reaching. We hypothesize that many people with mild to moderate cerebellar ataxia can learn on short and long time scales using a reinforcement motor learning mechanism, and this may benefit them over weeks of training. PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Biotin, a member of the family of water-soluble vitamins, is indispensable for normal cellular functions due to its critical roles in fatty acid, glucose and amino acid metabolism; the vitamin also plays important roles in normal immune function and in gene expression. Thus, it is not surprising that disturbance in normal biotin homeostasis (biotin deficiency and sub-optimal levels) leads to negative metabolic and health consequences. Such disturbances have been reported with increased frequency in recent years and shown to occur in a variety of conditions that include inflammatory bowel diseases, chronic alcoholism, in inborn errors of biotin metabolism, long-term use of anticonvulsant drugs, and during pregnancy. Thus, studies that are aimed at improving biotin body homeostasis are of clear physiological and nutritional importance.  We have known for some times that the intestinal biotin absorption process is via a Na+-dependent and regulated carrier-mediated process. In studies performed during the current funding period, we have generated an SMVT knockout mouse model and showed that the SMVT system is the only biotin uptake system that operates in the gut. Surprisingly, however, we observed that all the SMVT-/- mice develop spontaneous active intestinal inflammation, especially in the cecum. The latter suggests a possible role for biotin/ SMVT in the maintenance of normal intestinal health. We plan in this proposal to further characterize this intestinal phenotype and to delineate the mechanisms that lead to its development. We also aim at determining the mechanisms involved in the inhibition of biotin absorption that we recently observed as a result of salmonella infection, and following exposure to pro-inflammatory cytokines (as in inflammatory bowel diseases), and to bacterial LPS (as in infection with gram negative enteric pathogens) affect the absorption of the indispensable micronutrient biotin in the gut. Finally, we aim at delineating the epigenetic/molecular mechanisms involved in the inhibitory effect of chronic exposure to alcohol (the most common and costly drug abuse) on transcription of the SLC5A6 gene (i. e., the gene that encodes SMVT).
PROJECT_TITLE: INTESTINAL BIOTIN ABSORPTION: PHYSIOLOGICAL AND PATHOPHYSIOLOGICAL ASPECTS
